turn.text: It could have been, under Title VII.
Perhaps not under the Equal Pay Act.
That's an open question, whether there's a private remedy against unions under the Equal Pay Act.
That's a question that the Commission has not yet resolved.
For the reasons stated in our brief, we submit that the case should be dismissed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Lacovara, you have three minutes left.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
The Commission, in response to this colloquy about whether an employer may conceivably be an aggrieved party entitled to file a charge, did adopt the position that Mr. Wallace acknowledged.
This is printed on page 12A of our reply brief.
This is from the Commision's brief in the Court of Appeals.
The Commision said that for the first time it faced that question when it was asked by the Court of Appeals what its position was on contribution.
And it said that the Commission believes that in certain circumstances an employer might be able to file a charge as an aggrieved party.

That is eight years after the charges were filed against Northwest, and I submit it would be highly inequitable to the Court to block a contribution claim on the basis of a still unsettled and unadjudicated--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If during your bargaining negotiations, and this is in substance what you allege, you were being forced by the union to enter into a discriminatory bargain, couldn't you then have invoked the provisions of 703(c)(3)... whatever it is, and then filed your charge that, don't let the union put this kind of pressure on us?

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --The answer, Mr. Justice Stevens, is I don't know.
Not until eight years after all these events took place did the Commision ever indicate that an employer could file a charge.
As far as--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the statute has been there all the time, and one can read it, and it says that a person aggrieved can file a charge.
And if you were aggrieved under that section, I don't know why you couldn't file a charge.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --As far as we've been able to ascertain, the Commission in the 16 years since that statute has been in effect has never entertained a charge from an employer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, maybe an employer has never tried.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: That's entirely possible.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: So that you just... you recited it, the Commission said for the first time we've been asked about it in the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: That's right.
And I concede--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: As soon as they're asked about it, they say yes.
The Commission said a lot of things in the Court of Appeals that it's now changed its tune on.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

My principal point, though, may it please the Court, is that this discussion about whether Northwest could have filed the charge is irrelevant, as the 3rd Circuit held in the Glus case, and as the other federal courts have held in sustaining claims--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's not irrelevant if we consider it a jurisdictional prerequisite to litigating under Title VII.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --Yes.

My submission, Justice Stevens, is that it is not a jurisdictional prerequisite, and that's why it's irrelevant, that's what the lower courts have held when they've said that a contribution claim really is a federal common law claim, not a Title VII claim.
And it doesn't make any difference.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Except the Court of Appeals, in, this case.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: Except the Court of Appeals in this case, which didn't reach the Title VII issue.
It stopped short of reaching it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Lacovara, may I just ask you, does your brief cite any cases in this Court, or other, federal cases for that matter, which have held that there may be a suit for contribution unless there is statutory authority for it?

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: Yes--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Even without statutory authority?

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --Oh, yes, absolutely.
For example, Cooper Stevedoring--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --Cooper Stevedoring.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: This is in the maritime?

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: It's in the maritime field.
We do cite other cases in 417.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, maritime's a little unique, isn't it?
Well, anyway--

turn.speaker: philip_a_lacovara
turn.label: Mr. Philip A. Lacovara
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at <ten o'clock>[= 10:00].
